Dialogue.Student: Hi, I’m Zara Patel. This is my first time here.
Dialogue.Counselor: Hello, Zara! It’s nice to meet you. How are you feeling today?
Dialogue.Student: I’m feeling a bit overwhelmed. I just came back from an internship where I saw a lot of environmental issues, and now I’m questioning if I made enough of an impact.
Dialogue.Counselor: I’m sorry to hear that. It’s really understandable to feel that way after witnessing such challenges. Can you share more about what specifically is troubling you?
Dialogue.Student: I just feel inadequate compared to what needs to be done. I’ve been thinking if my contributions were really worth it.
Dialogue.Counselor: It’s natural to have those feelings, especially in a challenging field like environmental advocacy. Have you had a chance to talk about your experiences with someone?
Dialogue.Student: I spoke to my brother Rohan. He listens, but I still feel heavy about it.
Dialogue.Counselor: It’s good that you have someone supportive like Rohan. It's okay to not have all the answers right now. Sometimes just processing your feelings is an important step.

Dialogue.Student: Hey, I’m back. I’m struggling to focus in my classes this semester.
Dialogue.Counselor: Hi Zara! I’m glad to see you again. What’s making it hard for you to focus?
Dialogue.Student: I keep thinking about not making an impact in my field. I’m also working on a group project about sustainable practices, but I feel anxious about sharing my ideas.
Dialogue.Counselor: That sounds really tough. It’s normal to feel anxious about contributing, especially when you have doubts about your value. What’s holding you back from sharing your thoughts?
Dialogue.Student: Mia, a classmate, seems to dominate the discussions a lot. I feel overshadowed and think my ideas won’t be valued.
Dialogue.Counselor: It’s understandable to feel overshadowed. Have you considered discussing your ideas with a smaller group first or jotting them down before meetings?
Dialogue.Student: I haven’t tried that; I just freeze up when I get the chance to speak.
Dialogue.Counselor: Preparing your thoughts ahead of time could help. It might also ease your anxiety about contributing.

Dialogue.Student: Hi again. I’ve been really withdrawing from my group lately. I feel so isolated.
Dialogue.Counselor: Hello, Zara! I’m glad you came back in. Can you tell me more about what’s been going on?
Dialogue.Student: I just don’t feel like I can keep up with the group dynamics. I feel guilty for not participating.
Dialogue.Counselor: That’s a heavy feeling to carry. It’s normal to have ups and downs, especially in group settings. Does your group know how you feel?
Dialogue.Student: Mia reached out, and that made me feel guilty. I don’t want them to think I don’t care.
Dialogue.Counselor: It’s okay to have moments of struggle. They’re part of the process, and expressing your struggle can actually build more connection within the group.
Dialogue.Student: I just don’t want to bother them with my issues.
Dialogue.Counselor: You're not bothering them; you’re sharing a part of your journey. It can help others feel comfortable sharing their struggles as well.

Dialogue.Student: Hi! I had an important talk with my mother, and I feel ready to re-engage with my group.
Dialogue.Counselor: That’s fantastic, Zara! What did your mother say that helped you?
Dialogue.Student: She encouraged me to focus on progress rather than perfection and to connect more with my peers.
Dialogue.Counselor: That’s a powerful realization. How do you plan to approach your group after this new motivation?
Dialogue.Student: I decided to attend the next group meeting and share my insights from my internship. I want to contribute and feel valued.
Dialogue.Counselor: That’s a great step forward! How do you feel about sharing your thoughts now?
Dialogue.Student: I’m still nervous, but I believe my experiences can help make an impact. I want to be part of the conversation.
Dialogue.Counselor: That’s the spirit! Your voice matters, and I’m sure your contributions will enrich the project. You’ve got this!
Dialogue.Student: Thank you for all your support! I’m feeling hopeful and rejuvenated.
Dialogue.Counselor: It was my pleasure, Zara. Remember, I’m here for you, so don’t hesitate to reach out again. Good luck, and take care!
